1. Vector Analysis

1.1 Products of Three Vectors

  • Scalar triple product

A⋅(B×C)=B⋅(C×A)=C⋅(A×B)\mathbf{A} \cdot(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{C})=\mathbf{B} \cdot(\mathbf{C} \times \mathbf{A})=\mathbf{C} \cdot(\mathbf{A} \times \mathbf{B}) A⋅(B×C)=B⋅(C×A)=C⋅(A×B)

  • Vector triple product

A×(B×C)=B(A⋅C)−C(A⋅B)\mathbf{A} \times(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{C})=\mathbf{B}(\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{C})-\mathbf{C}(\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{B}) A×(B×C)=B(A⋅C)−C(A⋅B)

​ It is known as **"back-cab"**rule. (BAC-CAB)

(A×B)×C=B(A⋅C)−A(B⋅C)(\mathbf{A} \times\mathbf{B}) \times \mathbf{C}=\mathbf{B}(\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{C})-\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{B} \cdot \mathbf{C}) (A×B)×C=B(A⋅C)−A(B⋅C)

  • Cartesian Coordinates

(u1,u2,u3)=(x,y,z)\left(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}\right)=(x, y, z) (u1​,u2​,u3​)=(x,y,z)

A=axAx+ayAy+azAz\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{a}_{x} A_{x}+\mathbf{a}_{\mathbf{y}} A_{y}+\mathbf{a}_{z} A_{z} A=ax​Ax​+ay​Ay​+az​Az​

(u1,u2,u3)=(r,ϕ,z)\left(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}\right)=(r, \phi, z) (u1​,u2​,u3​)=(r,ϕ,z)

A=arAr+aϕAϕ+azAz\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{a}_{\boldsymbol{r}} A_{\boldsymbol{r}}+\mathbf{a}_{\phi} A_{\phi}+\mathbf{a}_{\mathbf{z}} \boldsymbol{A}_{z} A=ar​Ar​+aϕ​Aϕ​+az​Az​

  • Spherical Coordinates

(u1,u2,u3)=(R,θ,ϕ)\left(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}\right)=(R, \theta, \phi) (u1​,u2​,u3​)=(R,θ,ϕ)

A=aRAR+aθAθ+aϕAϕ\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{a}_{\boldsymbol{R}} A_{R}+\mathbf{a}_{\theta} A_{\theta}+\mathbf{a}_{\phi} A_{\phi} A=aR​AR​+aθ​Aθ​+aϕ​Aϕ​

R^⋅x^=cos⁡φ0sin⁡θ0θ^⋅x^=cos⁡ϕ0cos⁡θ0ϕ^⋅x^=−sin⁡ϕ0R^⋅y^=sin⁡φ0sin⁡θ0θ^⋅y^=sin⁡ϕ0cos⁡θ0ϕ^⋅y^=cos⁡ϕ0R^⋅z^=cos⁡θ0θ^⋅z^=−sin⁡θ0ϕ^⋅z^=0\begin{array}{ll} \hat{R} \cdot \hat{x}=\cos \varphi_{0} \sin \theta_{0} & \hat{\theta} \cdot \hat{x}=\cos \phi_{0} \cos \theta_{0} & \hat{\phi} \cdot \hat{x}=-\sin \phi_{0} \\ \hat{R} \cdot \hat{y}=\sin \varphi_{0} \sin \theta_{0} & \hat{\theta} \cdot \hat{y}=\sin \phi_{0} \cos \theta_{0} & \hat{\phi} \cdot \hat{y}=\operatorname{cos} \phi_{0} \\ \hat{R} \cdot \hat{z}=\cos \theta_{0} & \hat{\theta} \cdot \hat{z}=-\sin \theta_{0} & \hat{\phi} \cdot \hat{z}=0 \end{array} R^⋅x^=cosφ0​sinθ0​R^⋅y^​=sinφ0​sinθ0​R^⋅z^=cosθ0​​θ^⋅x^=cosϕ0​cosθ0​θ^⋅y^​=sinϕ0​cosθ0​θ^⋅z^=−sinθ0​​ϕ^​⋅x^=−sinϕ0​ϕ^​⋅y^​=cosϕ0​ϕ^​⋅z^=0​

1.3 Gradient of a Scalar Field

We define the vector that represents both the magnitude and the direction of the maximum space rate of increase of a scalar as the gradient of that scalar.

∇V≜andVdn\nabla V \triangleq \mathbf{a}_{n} \frac{d V}{d n} ∇V≜an​dndV​

The directional derivative along dℓd \elldℓ is

dVdℓ=dVdndndℓ=dVdncos⁡α=dVdnan⋅aℓ=(∇V)⋅aℓ\begin{aligned} \frac{d V}{d \ell} &=\frac{d V}{d n} \frac{d n}{d \ell}=\frac{d V}{d n} \cos \alpha \\ &=\frac{d V}{d n} \mathbf{a}_{n} \cdot \mathbf{a}_{\ell}=(\mathbf{\nabla} V) \cdot \mathbf{a}_{\ell} \end{aligned} dℓdV​​=dndV​dℓdn​=dndV​cosα=dndV​an​⋅aℓ​=(∇V)⋅aℓ​​

dV=(∇V)⋅dℓd V=(\mathbf{\nabla} V) \cdot d \ell dV=(∇V)⋅dℓ

Formula for calculating gradient

∇V=au1∂Vh1∂u1+au2∂Vh2∂u2+au3∂Vh3∂u3\nabla V=\mathbf{a}_{u_{1}} \frac{\partial V}{h_{1} \partial u_{1}}+\mathbf{a}_{u_{2}} \frac{\partial V}{h_{2} \partial u_{2}}+\mathbf{a}_{u_{3}} \frac{\partial V}{h_{3} \partial u_{3}} ∇V=au1​​h1​∂u1​∂V​+au2​​h2​∂u2​∂V​+au3​​h3​∂u3​∂V​

1.4 Divergence of a Vector Field

We define the divergence of a vector field A at a point as the net outward flux of A per unit volume as the volume about the point tends to zero:

div⁡A≜lim⁡Δv→0∮sA⋅dsΔv\operatorname{div} \mathbf{A} \triangleq \lim _{\Delta v \rightarrow 0} \frac{\oint_{s} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{s}}{\Delta v} divA≜Δv→0lim​Δv∮s​A⋅ds​

∇⋅A≡div⁡A\mathbf{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{A} \equiv \operatorname{div} \mathbf{A} ∇⋅A≡divA

∇⋅A=1h1h2h3[∂∂u1(h2h3A1)+∂∂u2(h1h3A2)+∂∂u3(h1h2A3)]\nabla \cdot \mathbf{A}=\frac{1}{h_{1} h_{2} h_{3}}\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial u_{1}}\left(h_{2} h_{3} A_{1}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial u_{2}}\left(h_{1} h_{3} A_{2}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial u_{3}}\left(h_{1} h_{2} A_{3}\right)\right] ∇⋅A=h1​h2​h3​1​[∂u1​∂​(h2​h3​A1​)+∂u2​∂​(h1​h3​A2​)+∂u3​∂​(h1​h2​A3​)]

Divergence theorem

The volume integral of the divergence of a vector field equals the total outward flux of the vector through the surface that bounds the volume.

∫V∇⋅Adv=∮SA⋅ds\int_{V} \mathbf{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{A} d v=\oint_{S} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{s} ∫V​∇⋅Adv=∮S​A⋅ds

1.5 Curl of a vector field

The curl of a vector field is a vector whose magnitude is the maximum net circulation of A per unit area as the area tends to zero and whose direction is the normal direction of the area when the area is oriented to make the net circulation maximum.

∇×A=1h1h2h3∣au1h1au2h2au3h3∂∂u1∂∂u2∂∂u3h1A1h2A2h3A3∣\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=\frac{1}{h_{1} h_{2} h_{3}}\left|\begin{array}{lll} \mathbf{a}_{u_{1}} h_{1} & \mathbf{a}_{u_{2}} h_{2} & \mathbf{a}_{u_{3}} h_{3} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial u_{1}} & \frac{\partial}{\partial u_{2}} & \frac{\partial}{\partial u_{3}} \\ h_{1} A_{1} & h_{2} A_{2} & h_{3} A_{3} \end{array}\right| ∇×A=h1​h2​h3​1​​au1​​h1​∂u1​∂​h1​A1​​au2​​h2​∂u2​∂​h2​A2​​au3​​h3​∂u3​∂​h3​A3​​​

Stokes's Theorem

Surface integral of the curl of a vector field over an open surface is equal to the closed line integral of the vector along the contour bounding the surface.

∫s(∇×A)⋅ds=∮CA⋅dℓ\int_{s}(\nabla \times \mathbf{A}) \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\oint_{C} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \ell ∫s​(∇×A)⋅ds=∮C​A⋅dℓ

1.6 Two Null Identities

∇×(∇V)≡0\begin{array}{l} \nabla \times(\nabla V) \equiv 0 \end{array} ∇×(∇V)≡0​

∇⋅(∇×A)≡0\nabla \cdot(\nabla \times \mathbf{A}) \equiv 0 ∇⋅(∇×A)≡0

1.7 Helmholtz's Theorem

A vector field is determined to within an additive constant if both its divergence and its curl are specified everywhere.

F=−∇V+∇×A\mathbf{F}=-\nabla V+\nabla \times \mathbf{A} F=−∇V+∇×A

2. Static Electric Fields

2.1 Fundamental Postulates of Electrostatics in Free Space

Two fundamental postulates of electrostatics in free space.

∇⋅E=ρϵ0∇×E=0\begin{array}{l} \nabla \cdot \mathbf{E}=\frac{\rho}{\epsilon_{0}} \\ \nabla \times \mathbf{E}=0 \end{array} ∇⋅E=ϵ0​ρ​∇×E=0​

 Postulates of Electrostatics in Free Space  Differential Form  Integral Form ∇⋅E=ρϵ0∮SE⋅ds=Qϵ0∇×E=0∮CE⋅dℓ=0\begin{array}{|cc|} \hline {\text { Postulates of Electrostatics in Free Space }} \\ \hline \text { Differential Form } & \text { Integral Form } \\ \hline \mathbf{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}=\frac{\rho}{\epsilon_{0}} & \oint_{S} \mathbf{E} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\frac{Q}{\epsilon_{0}} \\ \nabla \times \mathbf{E}=0 & \oint_{C} \mathbf{E} \cdot d \ell=0 \\ \hline \end{array}  Postulates of Electrostatics in Free Space  Differential Form ∇⋅E=ϵ0​ρ​∇×E=0​ Integral Form ∮S​E⋅ds=ϵ0​Q​∮C​E⋅dℓ=0​​

2.2 Coulomb's Law

E=aRER=aRq4πϵ0R2( V/m)\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{a}_{R} E_{R}=\mathbf{a}_{R} \frac{q}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} R^{2}} \quad(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) E=aR​ER​=aR​4πϵ0​R2q​( V/m)

Ep=q(R−R′)4πϵ0∣R−R′∣3( V/m)\mathbf{E}_{p}=\frac{q\left(\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{R}^{\prime}\right)}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}\left|\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{R}^{\prime}\right|^{3}} \quad(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) Ep​=4πϵ0​∣R−R′∣3q(R−R′)​( V/m)

E=0\mathbf{E}=0E=0 everywhere inside a conducting shell.

2.3 Electric Field Due to System of Discrete Charges

Suppose an electrostatic field is created by a group of nnn discrete point charges located at different positions.

E=14πϵ0∑k=1nqk(R−Rk′)∣R−Rk′∣3( V/m)\mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{q_{k}\left(\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{R}_{k}^{\prime}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{R}_{k}^{\prime}\right|^{3}} \quad(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) E=4πϵ0​1​k=1∑n​∣R−Rk′​∣3qk​(R−Rk′​)​( V/m)

Important Approximation

(1+x)n=1+nxifx→0(1+x)^n = 1 + nx \qquad if \quad x \to 0 (1+x)n=1+nxifx→0

Electric Dipole

E=q4πϵ0{R−d2∣R−d2∣3−R+d2∣R+d2∣3}\mathbf{E}=\frac{q}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}\left\{\frac{\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}}{\left|\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}\right|^{3}}-\frac{\mathbf{R}+\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}}{\left|\mathbf{R}+\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}\right|^{3}}\right\} E=4πϵ0​q​{​R−2d​​3R−2d​​−​R+2d​​3R+2d​​}

We can suppose that d≪Rd\ll Rd≪R

∣R−d2∣−3=[(R−d2)⋅(R−d2)]−3/2=[R2−R⋅d+d24]−3/2≅R−3[1−R⋅dR2]−3/2≅R−3[1+32R⋅dR2].\begin{aligned} \left|\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}\right|^{-3} &=\left[\left(\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{d}}{2}\right)\right]^{-3 / 2} \\ &=\left[\boldsymbol{R}^{2}-\mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{d}+\frac{d^{2}}{4}\right]^{-3 / 2} \\ & \cong R^{-3}\left[1-\frac{\mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{d}}{R^{2}}\right]^{-3 / 2} \\ & \cong R^{-3}\left[1+\frac{3}{2} \frac{\mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{d}}{R^{2}}\right]. \end{aligned} ​R−2d​​−3​=[(R−2d​)⋅(R−2d​)]−3/2=[R2−R⋅d+4d2​]−3/2≅R−3[1−R2R⋅d​]−3/2≅R−3[1+23​R2R⋅d​].​

Then the approximate formula for the electric field due to electric dipole is

E≅q4πϵ0R3[3R⋅dR2R−d].\mathbf{E} \cong \frac{q}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} R^{3}}\left[3 \frac{\mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{d}}{R^{2}} \mathbf{R}-\mathbf{d}\right]. E≅4πϵ0​R3q​[3R2R⋅d​R−d].

We define the product of the charge qqq and the vector d\mathbf{d}d (going from −q-q−q to +q+ q+q) as the electric dipole moment p\mathbf{p}p :

p=qd.\mathbf{p} = q \mathbf{d}. p=qd.

p=azp=p(aRcos⁡θ−aθsin⁡θ)R⋅p=Rpcos⁡θ,\begin{array}{c} \mathbf{p}=\mathbf{a}_{z} p=p\left(\mathbf{a}_{R} \cos \theta-\mathbf{a}_{\theta} \sin \theta\right) \\ \mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{p}=R p \cos \theta, \end{array} p=az​p=p(aR​cosθ−aθ​sinθ)R⋅p=Rpcosθ,​

E=p4πϵ0R3(aR2cos⁡θ+aθsin⁡θ)(V/m)\mathbf{E}=\frac{p}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} R^{3}}\left(\mathbf{a}_{R} 2 \cos \theta+\mathbf{a}_{\theta} \sin \theta\right) \quad(\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}) E=4πϵ0​R3p​(aR​2cosθ+aθ​sinθ)(V/m)

2.4 Electric Field Due to A Continuous Distribution of Charge

Volume Charge

E=14πϵ0∫V′ρRR3dv′(V/m).\mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{V^{\prime}} \rho \frac{\mathbf{R}}{R^{3}} d v^{\prime} \quad(\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}) . E=4πϵ0​1​∫V′​ρR3R​dv′(V/m).

Surface Charge

E=14πϵ0∫S′aRρsR2ds′(V/m)\mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{S^{\prime}} \mathbf{a}_{R} \frac{\rho_{s}}{R^{2}} d s^{\prime} \quad(\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}) E=4πϵ0​1​∫S′​aR​R2ρs​​ds′(V/m)

Infinite Surface Charge

E=azEz=azρs2ϵ0,z>0E=−azEz=−azρs2ϵ0,z<0\begin{array}{l} \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{a}_{z} E_{z}=\mathbf{a}_{z} \frac{\rho_{s}}{2 \epsilon_{0}}, \quad z>0 \\ \mathbf{E}=-\mathbf{a}_{z} E_{z}=-\mathbf{a}_{z} \frac{\rho_{s}}{2 \epsilon_{0}}, \quad z<0 \end{array} E=az​Ez​=az​2ϵ0​ρs​​,z>0E=−az​Ez​=−az​2ϵ0​ρs​​,z<0​

Line Charge

E=14πϵ0∫L′aRρℓR2dℓ′(V/m)\mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{L^{\prime}} \mathbf{a}_{R} \frac{\rho_{\ell}}{R^{2}} d \ell^{\prime} \quad(\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}) E=4πϵ0​1​∫L′​aR​R2ρℓ​​dℓ′(V/m)

Infinite Line Charge

E=arρℓ2πϵ0r( V/m)\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{a}_{r} \frac{\rho_{\ell}}{2 \pi \epsilon_{0} r} \quad(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) E=ar​2πϵ0​rρℓ​​( V/m)

2.5 Electric Potential

E=−∇V\mathbf{E}=-\nabla V E=−∇V

V21=V2−V1=−∫P1P2E⋅dℓV_{21} = V_{2} - V_{1} = -\int_{P_{1}}^{P_{2}} \mathbf{E} \cdot d \mathbf{\ell} V21​=V2​−V1​=−∫P1​P2​​E⋅dℓ

V=q4πϵ0R( V)V=\frac{q}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} R} \quad(\mathrm{~V}) V=4πϵ0​Rq​( V)

Discrete Point Charges

V=14πϵ0∑k=1nqk∣R−Rk′∣V=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{q_{k}}{\left|\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{R}_{k}^{\prime}\right|} V=4πϵ0​1​k=1∑n​∣R−Rk′​∣qk​​

Electric Dipole

V=p⋅aR4πϵ0R2( V)V=\frac{\mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{a}_{R}}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} R^{2}} \quad(\mathrm{~V}) V=4πϵ0​R2p⋅aR​​( V)

Volume Charge

V=14πϵ0∫V′ρRdv′V=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{V^{\prime}} \frac{\rho}{R} d v^{\prime} V=4πϵ0​1​∫V′​Rρ​dv′

Surface Charge

V=14πϵ0∫S′ρsRds′(V)V=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{S^{\prime}} \frac{\rho_{s}}{R} d s^{\prime} \quad(\mathrm{V}) V=4πϵ0​1​∫S′​Rρs​​ds′(V)

Line Charge

V=14πϵ0∫L′ρℓRdℓ′V=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{L^{\prime}} \frac{\rho_{\ell}}{R} d \ell^{\prime} V=4πϵ0​1​∫L′​Rρℓ​​dℓ′

If symmetry conditions exist such that a Gaussian surface can be constructed over which E⋅ds\mathbf{E} \cdot d \mathbf{s}E⋅ds is constant, it is always easier to determine E\mathbf{E}E directly. If not, we can determine E\mathbf{E}E by first finding VVV.

2.6 Conductors in Static Electric Field

 Inside a Conductor  (Under Static Conditions) ρ=0E=0\begin{array}{|c|} \hline \begin{array}{c} \text { Inside a Conductor } \\ \text { (Under Static Conditions) } \end{array} \\ \hline \rho=0 \\ \mathbf{E}=0\\ \hline \end{array}  Inside a Conductor  (Under Static Conditions) ​ρ=0E=0​​

Under static conditions the E\mathbf{E}E field on a conductor surface is everywhere normal to the surface. In other words, the surface of a conductor is an equipotential surface under static conditions.

 Boundary Conditions  at a Conductor/Free Space Interface Et=0En=ρsϵ0\begin{array}{|c|} \hline \begin{array}{c} \text { Boundary Conditions } \\ \text { at a Conductor/Free Space Interface } \end{array} \\ \hline E_{t}=0 \\ E_{n}=\frac{\rho_{s}}{\epsilon_{0}}\\ \hline \end{array}  Boundary Conditions  at a Conductor/Free Space Interface ​Et​=0En​=ϵ0​ρs​​​​

3.7 Dielectrics in Static Electric Field

Polarization Vector P\mathbf{P}P

P=lim⁡Δv→0∑k=1nΔvpkΔv(C/m2)\mathbf{P}=\lim _{\Delta v \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n \Delta v} \mathbf{p}_{k}}{\Delta v} \quad\left(\mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) P=Δv→0lim​Δv∑k=1nΔv​pk​​(C/m2)

Vector Identity

∇′⋅(fA)=f∇′⋅A+A⋅∇′f\boldsymbol{\nabla}^{\prime} \cdot(f \mathbf{A})=f \mathbf{\nabla}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{A}+\mathbf{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla}^{\prime} f ∇′⋅(fA)=f∇′⋅A+A⋅∇′f

Potential of Dielectrics

V=14πϵ0∮S′P⋅an′Rds′+14πϵ0∫V′(−∇′⋅P)Rdv′V=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \oint_{S^{\prime}} \frac{\mathbf{P} \cdot \mathbf{a}_{n}^{\prime}}{R} d s^{\prime}+\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{V^{\prime}} \frac{\left(-\mathbf{\nabla}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right)}{R} d v^{\prime} V=4πϵ0​1​∮S′​RP⋅an′​​ds′+4πϵ0​1​∫V′​R(−∇′⋅P)​dv′

ρps=P⋅anρp=−∇⋅P\begin{array}{l} \rho_{p s}=\mathbf{P} \cdot \mathbf{a}_{n} \\ \rho_{p}=-\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P} \end{array} ρps​=P⋅an​ρp​=−∇⋅P​

These are referred to as polarization charge densities or bound-charge densities. In other words, a polarized dielectric may be replaced by an equivalent polarization surface charge density ρps\rho_{p s}ρps​ and an equivalent polarization volume charge density ρp\rho_{p}ρp​ for field calculations:

V=14πϵ0∮S′ρpsRds′+14πϵ0∫V′ρpRdv′V=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \oint_{S^{\prime}} \frac{\rho_{p s}}{R} d s^{\prime}+\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \int_{V^{\prime}} \frac{\rho_{p}}{R} d v^{\prime} V=4πϵ0​1​∮S′​Rρps​​ds′+4πϵ0​1​∫V′​Rρp​​dv′

2.8 Electric Flux Density and Dielectric Constant

Electric Flux Density (Electric Displacement)

D=ϵ0E+P(C/m2)\mathbf{D}=\epsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P} \quad\left(\mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) D=ϵ0​E+P(C/m2)

The use of the vector D\mathbf{D}D enables us to write a divergence relation between the electric field and the distribution of free charges in any medium without the necessity of dealing explicitly with the polarization vector P\mathbf{P}P or the polarization charge density ρp\rho_{p}ρp​. We obtain the new equation

∇⋅D=ρ(C/m3)\nabla \cdot \mathbf{D}=\rho \quad\left(\mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\right) ∇⋅D=ρ(C/m3)

∮sD⋅ds=Q (C) \oint_{s} \mathbf{D} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=Q \quad \text { (C) } ∮s​D⋅ds=Q (C) 

Electric Susceptibility

P=ϵ0χeE\mathbf{P}=\epsilon_{0} \chi_{e} \mathbf{E} P=ϵ0​χe​E

A dielectric medium is linear if χe\chi_{e}χe​ is independent of EEE and homogeneous if χe\chi_{e}χe​ is independent of space coordinates.

D=ϵ0(1+χe)E=ϵ0ϵrE=ϵE(C/m2)\begin{aligned} \mathbf{D} &=\epsilon_{0}\left(1+\chi_{e}\right) \mathbf{E} \\ &=\epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r} \mathbf{E}=\epsilon \mathbf{E} \quad\left(\mathbf{C} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) \end{aligned} D​=ϵ0​(1+χe​)E=ϵ0​ϵr​E=ϵE(C/m2)​

where

ϵr=1+χe=ϵϵ0\epsilon_{r}=1+\chi_{e}=\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_{0}} ϵr​=1+χe​=ϵ0​ϵ​

is a dimensionless quantity known as the relative permittivity or the dielectric constant of the medium. ϵ\epsilonϵ is the absolute permittivity of the medium and is measured in farads per meter (F/m)(\mathrm{F} / \mathrm{m})(F/m).

Dielectric Breakdown

The maximum electric field intensity that a dielectric material can withstand without breakdown i the the dielectric strength of the material.

2.9 Boundary Conditions for Electrostatic Fields

E1t=E2t( V/m)E_{1 t}=E_{2 t} \quad(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) E1t​=E2t​( V/m)

This states that the tangential component of an E field is continuous across an interface.

D1n−D2n=ρs(C/m2)D_{1 n}-D_{2 n}=\rho_{s} \quad\left(\mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) D1n​−D2n​=ρs​(C/m2)

The normal component of DDD field is discontinuous across an interface where a surface charge exists --- the amount of discontinuity being equal to the surface charge density.

2.10 Capacitance and Capacitors

Q=CV，Q=C V， Q=CV，

where the constant of proportionality CCC is called the capacitance of the isolated conducting body.

Method of Capacitance Calculation

  1. Choose an appropriate coordinate system for the given geometry.
  2. Assume charges +Q+Q+Q and −Q-Q−Q on the conductors.
  3. Find E\mathbf{E}E from QQQ by Eq. (3-122), Gauss's law, or other relations.
  4. Find V12V_{12}V12​ by evaluating

V12=−∫21E⋅dℓV_{12}=-\int_{2}^{1} \mathbf{E} \cdot d \ell V12​=−∫21​E⋅dℓ

​ from the conductor carrying −Q-Q−Q to the other carrying +Q+Q+Q. 5. Find CCC by taking the ratio Q/V12Q / V_{12}Q/V12​.

1Csr=1C1+1C2+⋯+1Cn\frac{1}{C_{s r}}=\frac{1}{C_{1}}+\frac{1}{C_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{C_{n}} Csr​1​=C1​1​+C2​1​+⋯+Cn​1​

pijp_{ij}pij​'s are called the coefficients of potential, which are constants whose values depend on the shape and position of the conductors as well as the permittivity of the surrounding medium. In an isolated system, the net electric charge should be zero.

Q1=c11V1+c12V2+⋯+c1NVNQ2=c21V1+c22V2+⋯+c2NVN⋮QN=cN1V1+cN2V2+⋯+cNNVN\begin{aligned} &Q_{1}=c_{11} V_{1}+c_{12} V_{2}+\cdots+c_{1 N} V_{N} \\ &Q_{2}=c_{21} V_{1}+c_{22} V_{2}+\cdots+c_{2 N} V_{N} \\ &\vdots \\ &Q_{N}=c_{N 1} V_{1}+c_{N 2} V_{2}+\cdots+c_{N N} V_{N} \end{aligned} ​Q1​=c11​V1​+c12​V2​+⋯+c1N​VN​Q2​=c21​V1​+c22​V2​+⋯+c2N​VN​⋮QN​=cN1​V1​+cN2​V2​+⋯+cNN​VN​​

ciic_{ii}cii​'s are called the coefficients of capacitance (positive), which equal the rations of the charge QiQ_iQi​ on the potential ViV_iVi​ of the $i$th conductor with all other conductors grounded. The cijc_{ij}cij​'s (i≠ji \neq ji=j) are called the coefficients of induction (negative). The condition of reciprocity guarantees that pij=pjip_{ij} = p _{ji}pij​=pji​ and cij=cjic_{ij} = c_{ji}cij​=cji​.

Q1=c11V1+c12V2+c13V3Q2=c12V1+c22V2+c23V3Q3=c13V1+c23V2+c33V3\begin{aligned} &Q_{1}=c_{11} V_{1}+c_{12} V_{2}+c_{13} V_{3} \\ &Q_{2}=c_{12} V_{1}+c_{22} V_{2}+c_{23} V_{3} \\ &Q_{3}=c_{13} V_{1}+c_{23} V_{2}+c_{33} V_{3} \end{aligned} ​Q1​=c11​V1​+c12​V2​+c13​V3​Q2​=c12​V1​+c22​V2​+c23​V3​Q3​=c13​V1​+c23​V2​+c33​V3​​

The potential energy of a group of NNN discrete point charges at rest is

Vk=14πϵ0∑j=1(j≠k)NQjRjkV_{k}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \sum_{j=1 \atop(j \neq k)}^{N} \frac{Q_{j}}{R_{j k}} Vk​=4πϵ0​1​(j=k)j=1​∑N​Rjk​Qj​​

WeW_{e}We​ represents only the interaction energy (mutual energy) and does not include the work required to assemble the individual point charges themselves (self-energy).

Continuous Charge Distribution

We=12∫V′ρVdv(J)\begin{aligned} &W_{e}=\frac{1}{2} \int_{V^{\prime}} \rho V d v &(\mathbf{J}) \end{aligned} ​We​=21​∫V′​ρVdv​(J)​

WeW_{e}We​ includes the work (self-energy) required to assemble the distribution of macroscopic charges, because it is the energy of interaction of every infinitesimal charge element with all other infinitesimal charge elements.

We=12∫V′D⋅Edv(J)W_{e}=\frac{1}{2} \int_{V^{\prime}} \mathbf{D} \cdot \mathbf{E} d v \quad(\mathbf{J}) We​=21​∫V′​D⋅Edv(J)

3. Solution of Electrostatic Problems

3.1 Poisson's and Laplace's Equation

Poisson's Equation

∇2V=−ρϵ\nabla^{2} V=-\frac{\rho}{\epsilon} ∇2V=−ϵρ​

∂2V∂x2+∂2V∂y2+∂2V∂z2=−ρϵ(V/m2)\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial y^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial z^{2}}=-\frac{\rho}{\epsilon} \quad\left(\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) ∂x2∂2V​+∂y2∂2V​+∂z2∂2V​=−ϵρ​(V/m2)

Cylindrical coordinates:

∇2V=1r∂∂r(r∂V∂r)+1r2∂2V∂ϕ2+∂2V∂z2\nabla^{2} V=\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r \frac{\partial V}{\partial r}\right)+\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \phi^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial z^{2}} ∇2V=r1​∂r∂​(r∂r∂V​)+r21​∂ϕ2∂2V​+∂z2∂2V​

Spherical coordinates:

∇2V=1R2∂∂R(R2∂V∂R)+1R2sin⁡θ∂∂θ(sin⁡θ∂V∂θ)+1R2sin⁡2θ∂2V∂ϕ2\nabla^{2} V=\frac{1}{R^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial R}\left(R^{2} \frac{\partial V}{\partial R}\right)+\frac{1}{R^{2} \sin \theta} \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\left(\sin \theta \frac{\partial V}{\partial \theta}\right)+\frac{1}{R^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta} \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \phi^{2}} ∇2V=R21​∂R∂​(R2∂R∂V​)+R2sinθ1​∂θ∂​(sinθ∂θ∂V​)+R2sin2θ1​∂ϕ2∂2V​

Laplace's Equation

∇2V=0\nabla^{2} V=0 ∇2V=0

Uniqueness of Electrostatic Solutions

A solution of Poisson's equation that satisfies the given boundary conditions is a unique solution.

3.2 Method of Images

The method of replacing bounding surfaces by appropriate image charges in lieu of a formal solution of Poisson's or Laplace's equation is called the method of images.

would be needed at the center to make the sphere neutral.

4 Steady Electric Current

4.1 Current Density and Ohm's Law

ΔQ=Nqu⋅anΔsΔt (C). \Delta Q=N q \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{a}_{n} \Delta s \Delta t \text { (C). } ΔQ=Nqu⋅an​ΔsΔt (C). 

ΔI=ΔQΔt=Nqu⋅anΔs=Nqu⋅Δs\Delta I=\frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta t}=N q \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{a}_{n} \Delta s=N q \mathbf{u} \cdot \Delta \mathbf{s} ΔI=ΔtΔQ​=Nqu⋅an​Δs=Nqu⋅Δs

Current Density

J=Nqu(A/m2)\mathbf{J}=N q \mathbf{u} \quad\left(\mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) J=Nqu(A/m2)

I=∫SJ⋅ds (A). I=\int_{S} \mathbf{J} \cdot d \mathbf{s} \text { (A). } I=∫S​J⋅ds (A). 

J=ρu(A/m2)\mathbf{J}=\rho \mathbf{u} \left(\mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) J=ρu(A/m2)

Electron Mobility

u=−μeE(m/s)\mathbf{u}=-\mu_{e} \mathbf{E} \quad(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}) u=−μe​E(m/s)

J=σE(A/m2)\mathbf{J}=\sigma \mathbf{E} \quad\left(\mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) J=σE(A/m2)

where the proportionality constant, σ=−ρeμe\sigma=-\rho_{e} \mu_{e}σ=−ρe​μe​, is a macroscopic constitutive parameter of the medium called conductivity.

R=ℓσSR=\frac{\ell}{\sigma S} R=σSℓ​

4.2 Electromotive Force and Kirchhoff's Voltage Law

For an ohmic material J=σE\mathbf{J}=\sigma \mathbf{E}J=σE,

∮c1σJ⋅dℓ=0,\oint_{c} \frac{1}{\sigma} \mathbf{J} \cdot d \ell=0, ∮c​σ1​J⋅dℓ=0,

which tells us that a steady current cannot be maintained in the same direction in a closed circuit by an electrostatic field.

V=∫21Ei⋅dℓ=−∫21E⋅dℓ\mathscr{V}=\int_{2}^{1} \mathbf{E}_{i} \cdot d \ell=-\int_{2}^{1} \mathbf{E} \cdot d \ell V=∫21​Ei​⋅dℓ=−∫21​E⋅dℓ

EiE_iEi​ is called impressed electric field intensity.

5 Static Magnetic Fields

Fm=qu×B,(N)\mathbf{F}_{m}=q \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}, \quad(\mathbf{N}) Fm​=qu×B,(N)

where u(m/s)\mathbf{u}(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s})u(m/s) is the velocity vector, and B\mathbf{B}B is measured in webers per square meter (Wb/m2)\left(\mathrm{Wb} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right)(Wb/m2) or teslas $(\mathrm{T}) .$The total electromagnetic force on a charge qqq is, then, F=Fe+Fm;\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{F}_{e}+\mathbf{F}_{m} ;F=Fe​+Fm​; that is,

F=q(E+u×B),(N)\mathbf{F}=q(\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}), \quad(\mathbf{N}) F=q(E+u×B),(N)

which is called Lorentz's force equation.

5.1 Fundamental Postulates of Magnetostatics in Free Space

 Postulates of Magnetostatics in  Free Space  Differential Form  Integral Form ∇⋅B=0∮SB⋅ds=0∇×B=μ0J∮CB⋅dℓ=μ0I\begin{array}{|cc|} \hline {\begin{array}{c} \text { Postulates of Magnetostatics in } \text { Free Space } \end{array}} \\ \hline \text { Differential Form } & \text { Integral Form } \\ \hline \mathbf{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{B}=0 & \oint_{S} \mathbf{B} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=0 \\ \nabla \times \mathbf{B}=\mu_{0} \mathbf{J} & \oint_{C} \mathbf{B} \cdot d \ell=\mu_{0} I \\ \hline \end{array}  Postulates of Magnetostatics in  Free Space ​ Differential Form ∇⋅B=0∇×B=μ0​J​ Integral Form ∮S​B⋅ds=0∮C​B⋅dℓ=μ0​I​​

There are no magnetic flow sources, and the magnetic flux lines always close upon themselves. The law of conservation of magnetic flux and Ampere's circuital law.

5.2 Vector Magnetic Potential

B=∇×A(T)\mathbf{B}=\mathbf{\nabla} \times \mathbf{A} \quad(\mathrm{T}) B=∇×A(T)

The vector field AAA so defined is called the vector magnetic potential.

Coulomb Condition

∇⋅A=0,∇2A=−μ0J\nabla \cdot \mathbf{A}=0, \\ \nabla^{2} \mathbf{A}=-\mu_{0} \mathbf{J} ∇⋅A=0,∇2A=−μ0​J

This is a vector Poisson's equation

In Cartesian coordinates,

∇2Ax=−μ0Jx∇2Ay=−μ0Jy∇2Az=−μ0Jz\begin{aligned} &\nabla^{2} A_{x}=-\mu_{0} J_{x} \\ &\nabla^{2} A_{y}=-\mu_{0} J_{y} \\ &\nabla^{2} A_{z}=-\mu_{0} J_{z} \end{aligned} ​∇2Ax​=−μ0​Jx​∇2Ay​=−μ0​Jy​∇2Az​=−μ0​Jz​​

The solution is

A=μ04π∫V′JRdv′(Wb/m)\mathbf{A}=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \int_{V^{\prime}} \frac{\mathbf{J}}{R} d v^{\prime} \quad(\mathrm{Wb} / \mathrm{m}) A=4πμ0​​∫V′​RJ​dv′(Wb/m)

Vector magnetic potential's line integral around any closed path equals the total magnetic flux passing through the area enclosed by the path.

Φ=∫S(∇×A)⋅ds=∮CA⋅dℓ\Phi=\int_{S}(\nabla \times \mathbf{A}) \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\oint_{C} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \ell Φ=∫S​(∇×A)⋅ds=∮C​A⋅dℓ

5.4 The Magnetic Dipole

where m=azIπb2=azIS=azm( A⋅m2)\mathbf{m}=\mathbf{a}_{z} I \pi b^{2}=\mathbf{a}_{z} I S=\mathbf{a}_{z} m \quad\left(\mathrm{~A} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{2}\right)m=az​Iπb2=az​IS=az​m( A⋅m2) is defined as the magnetic dipole moment

5.5 Magnetization and Equivalent Current Densities

Magnetization vector

M=lim⁡Δv→0∑k=1nΔvmkΔv( A/m)\mathbf{M}=\lim _{\Delta v \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n \Delta v} \mathbf{m}_{k}}{\Delta v} \quad(\mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}) M=Δv→0lim​Δv∑k=1nΔv​mk​​( A/m)

It is the volume density of magnetic dipole moment.

A=μ04π∫V′∇′×MRdv′+μ04π∮S′M×an′Rds′\mathbf{A}=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \int_{V^{\prime}} \frac{\mathbf{\nabla}^{\prime} \times \mathbf{M}}{R} d v^{\prime}+\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \oint_{S^{\prime}} \frac{\mathbf{M} \times \mathbf{a}_{n}^{\prime}}{R} d s^{\prime} A=4πμ0​​∫V′​R∇′×M​dv′+4πμ0​​∮S′​RM×an′​​ds′

The effect of the magnetization vector is equivalent to both a volume current density and a surface current density.

Jm=∇×M(A/m2)Jms=M×an( A/m)\begin{aligned} &\mathbf{J}_{m}=\nabla \times \mathbf{M} \quad\left(\mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right)\\ &\mathbf{J}_{m s}=\mathbf{M} \times \mathbf{a}_{n} \quad(\mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}) \end{aligned} ​Jm​=∇×M(A/m2)Jms​=M×an​( A/m)​

5.6 Magnetic Field Intensity and Relative Permeability

Magnetic Field Intensity

H=Bμ0−M(A/m)\mathbf{H}=\frac{\mathbf{B}}{\mu_{0}}-\mathbf{M} \quad(\mathbf{A} / \mathbf{m}) H=μ0​B​−M(A/m)

∇×H=J(A/m2)\mathbf{\nabla} \times \mathbf{H}=\mathbf{J} \quad\left(\mathbf{A} / \mathbf{m}^{2}\right) ∇×H=J(A/m2)

According to Stokes's theorem

∮CH⋅dℓ=I (A) \oint_{C} \mathbf{H} \cdot d \ell=I \quad \text { (A) } ∮C​H⋅dℓ=I (A) 

It is another form of Ampère's circuital law: It states that the circulation of the magnetic field intensity around any closed path is equal to the free current flowing through the surface bounded by the path.

When the magnetic properties of the medium are linear and isotropic, the magnetization is directly proportional to the magnetic field intensity:

M=χmH\mathbf{M}=\chi_{m} \mathbf{H} M=χm​H

where χm\chi_{m}χm​ is a dimensionless quantity called magnetic susceptibility.

B=μ0(1+χm)H=μ0μrH=μH(Wb/m2)\begin{array}{rlr} \mathbf{B} & =\mu_{0}\left(1+\chi_{m}\right) \mathbf{H} & \\ & =\mu_{0} \mu_{r} \mathbf{H}=\mu \mathbf{H} & \left(\mathbf{W b} / \mathbf{m}^{2}\right) \end{array} B​=μ0​(1+χm​)H=μ0​μr​H=μH​(Wb/m2)​

or

H=1μB(A/m)\mathbf{H}=\frac{1}{\mu} \mathbf{B} \quad(\mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}) H=μ1​B(A/m)

where

μr=1+χm=μμ0\mu_{r}=1+\chi_{m}=\frac{\mu}{\mu_{0}} μr​=1+χm​=μ0​μ​

is another dimensionless quantity known as the relative permeability of the medium. The parameter μ=μ0μr\mu=\mu_{0} \mu_{r}μ=μ0​μr​ is the absolute permeability (or sometimes just permeability) of the medium and is measured in H/m;χm\mathrm{H} / \mathrm{m} ; \chi_{m}H/m;χm​, and therefore μr\mu_{r}μr​, can be a function of space coordinates. For a simple medium - linear, isotropic, and homogeneous −χm-\chi_{m}−χm​ and μr\mu_{r}μr​ are constants.

5.7 Magnetic Circuits

Magnetomotive Force

∮CH⋅dℓ=NI=Vm\oint_{C} \mathbf{H} \cdot d \ell=N I=\mathscr{V}_{m} ∮C​H⋅dℓ=NI=Vm​

Φ≅BS\Phi \cong B S Φ≅BS

Φ=VmRf+Rg\Phi=\frac{\mathscr{V}_{m}}{\mathscr{R}_{f}+\mathscr{R}_{g}} Φ=Rf​+Rg​Vm​​

Rg=ℓgμ0S\mathscr{R}_{g}=\frac{\ell_{g}}{\mu_{0} S} Rg​=μ0​Sℓg​​

Rf=2πro−ℓgμS=ℓfμS\mathscr{R}_{f}=\frac{2 \pi r_{o}-\ell_{g}}{\mu S}=\frac{\ell_{f}}{\mu S} Rf​=μS2πro​−ℓg​​=μSℓf​​

Analogy

 Magnetic Circuits  Electric Circuits  mmf, Vm(=NI) emf, V magnetic flux, Φ electric current, I reluctance, R resistance, R permeability, μ conductivity, σ\begin{array}{|ll|} \hline \text { Magnetic Circuits } & \text { Electric Circuits } \\ \hline \text { mmf, } \mathscr{V}_{m}(=N I) & \text { emf, } \mathscr{V} \\ \text { magnetic flux, } \Phi & \text { electric current, } I \\ \text { reluctance, } \mathscr{R} & \text { resistance, } R \\ \text { permeability, } \mu & \text { conductivity, } \sigma \\ \hline \end{array}  Magnetic Circuits  mmf, Vm​(=NI) magnetic flux, Φ reluctance, R permeability, μ​ Electric Circuits  emf, V electric current, I resistance, R conductivity, σ​​

∑jNjIj=∑kRkΦk\sum_{j} N_{j} I_{j}=\sum_{k} \mathscr{R}_{k} \Phi_{k} j∑​Nj​Ij​=k∑​Rk​Φk​

It states that around a closed path in a magnetic circuit the algebraic sum of ampere-turns is equal to the algebraic sum of the products of the reluctances and fluxes.

∑jΦj=0\sum_{j} \Phi_{j}=0 j∑​Φj​=0

The algebraic sums of all the magnetic fluxes flowing out of a junction in a magnetic circuit is zero.

5.8 Behavior of Magnetic Materials

Diamagnetic, if μr≲1(χm\mu_{r} \lesssim 1\left(\chi_{m}\right.μr​≲1(χm​ is a very small negative number).

Paramagnetic, if μr≳1(χm\mu_{r} \gtrsim 1\left(\chi_{m}\right.μr​≳1(χm​ is a very small positive number).

Ferromagnetic, if μr≫1(χm\mu_{r} \gg 1\left(\chi_{m}\right.μr​≫1(χm​ is a large positive number).

Diamagnetic

  1. No net magnetic dipole moments without external magnetic field.
  2. With external magnetic field, there is a net magnetic dipole moment reducing B\mathbf{B}B
  3. No permanent magnetism

Paramagnetic

  1. There is net magnetic dipole moment without external magnetic field.
  2. A very weak induced magnetization with external magnetic field.

Ferromagnetic

  1. Magnetization can be many orders of magnitude larger than that of paramagnetic substances
  2. No net magnetization without external magnetic field due to random orientation in the various domains.
  3. The domains aligned with applied magnetic field with external magnetic field.

Hysteresis

The area of the hysteresis loop corresponds to energy loss (hysteresis loss) per unit volume per cycle.

Hard materials have fat hysteresis loops while soft materials have tall narrow hysteresis loops/

Curie Temperature

Above the curie temperature, a ferromagnetic material loses magnetization, reducing to paramagnetic substances.

5.9 Boundary Conditions for Magnetostatic Fields

B1n=B2n\boldsymbol{B}_{1 n}=\boldsymbol{B}_{2 n} B1n​=B2n​

an2×(H1−H2)=Js(A/m)\mathbf{a}_{n 2} \times\left(\mathbf{H}_{1}-\mathbf{H}_{2}\right)=\mathbf{J}_{s} \quad(\mathbf{A} / \mathbf{m}) an2​×(H1​−H2​)=Js​(A/m)

where an2\mathbf{a}_{n 2}an2​ is the outward unit normal from medium 2 at the interface.

H1t−H2t=Jsn( A/m)H_{1 t}-H_{2 t}=J_{s n} \quad(\mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}) H1t​−H2t​=Jsn​( A/m)

The tangential component of H is continuous across the boundary of almost all physical media; it is discontinuous only when an interface with an ideal perfect conductor or a superconductor is assumed.

5.10 Inductances and Inductors

Φ12=L12I1,\Phi_{12}=L_{12} I_{1}, Φ12​=L12​I1​,

where the proportionality constant L12L_{12}L12​ is called the mutual inductance between loops C1C_{1}C1​ and C2C_{2}C2​, with SI unit henry (H). In case C2C_{2}C2​ has N2N_{2}N2​ turns, the flux linkage Λ12\Lambda_{12}Λ12​ due to Φ12\Phi_{12}Φ12​ is

Λ12=N2Φ12\Lambda_{12}=N_{2} \Phi_{12} Λ12​=N2​Φ12​

So the mutual inductance generalizes to:

L12=Λ12I1(H)L_{12}=\frac{\Lambda_{12}}{I_{1}} \quad(\mathrm{H}) L12​=I1​Λ12​​(H)

The mutual inductance between two circuits is then the magnetic flux linkage with one circuit per unit current in the other.

L12=dΛ12dI1(H)L_{12}=\frac{d \Lambda_{12}}{d I_{1}} \quad(\mathrm{H}) L12​=dI1​dΛ12​​(H)

Some of the magnetic flux produced by I1I_{1}I1​ links only with C1C_{1}C1​ itself, and not with C2C_{2}C2​. The total flux linkage with C1C_{1}C1​ caused by I1I_{1}I1​ is

Λ11=N1Φ11>N1Φ12\Lambda_{11}=N_{1} \Phi_{11}>N_{1} \Phi_{12} Λ11​=N1​Φ11​>N1​Φ12​

The self-inductance of loop C1C_{1}C1​ is defined as the magnetic flux linkage per unit current in the loop itself, that is,

L11=Λ11I1(H)L_{11}=\frac{\Lambda_{11}}{I_{1}} \quad(\mathrm{H}) L11​=I1​Λ11​​(H)

for a linear medium. In general,

L11=dΛ11dI1(H)L_{11}=\frac{d \Lambda_{11}}{d I_{1}} \quad(\mathrm{H}) L11​=dI1​dΛ11​​(H)

The self-inductance of a loop or circuit depends on the geometrical shape and the physical arrangement of the conductor constituting the loop or circuit, as well as on the permeability of the medium. With a linear medium, self-inductance does not depend on the current in the loop or circuit. As a matter of fact, it exists regardless of whether the loop or circuit is open or closed, or whether it is near another loop or circuit.

Neumann formula

L12=μ04π∮C1∮C2dℓ1⋅dℓ2R(H)L_{12}=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \oint_{C_{1}} \oint_{C_{2}} \frac{d \ell_{1} \cdot d \ell_{2}}{R} \quad(\mathrm{H}) L12​=4πμ0​​∮C1​​∮C2​​Rdℓ1​⋅dℓ2​​(H)

where N1N_{1}N1​ and N2N_{2}N2​ have been absorbed in the contour integrals over the circuits C1C_{1}C1​ and C2C_{2}C2​ from one end to the other. It is a general formula requiring the evaluation of a double line integral.

Wm=12∑j=1N∑k=1NLjkIjIkW_{m}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \sum_{k=1}^{N} L_{j k} I_{j} I_{k} Wm​=21​j=1∑N​k=1∑N​Ljk​Ij​Ik​

5.12 Magnetic Forces and Torques

dFm=Idℓ×B(N)d \mathbf{F}_{m}=I d \ell \times \mathbf{B} \quad(\mathrm{N}) dFm​=Idℓ×B(N)

Fm=I∮Cdℓ×B(N)\mathbf{F}_{m}=I \oint_{C} d \ell \times \mathbf{B} \quad(\mathbf{N}) Fm​=I∮C​dℓ×B(N)

**Ampere's Law of Force **

F21=μ04πI1I2∮c1∮C2dℓ1×(dℓ2×aR21)R212(N)\mathbf{F}_{21}=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} I_{1} I_{2} \oint_{c_{1}} \oint_{C_{2}} \frac{d \ell_{1} \times\left(d \ell_{2} \times \mathbf{a}_{R_{21}}\right)}{R_{21}^{2}}(\mathbf{N}) F21​=4πμ0​​I1​I2​∮c1​​∮C2​​R212​dℓ1​×(dℓ2​×aR21​​)​(N)

The magnetic dipole moment of a circular circuits:

m=anI(πb2)=anIS\mathbf{m}=\mathbf{a}_{n} I\left(\pi b^{2}\right)=\mathbf{a}_{n} I S m=an​I(πb2)=an​IS

where an\mathbf{a}_{n}an​ is a unit vector in the direction of the right thumb (normal to the plane of the loop) as the fingers of the right hand follow the direction of the current, we can write

T=m×B(N⋅m)\mathbf{T}=\mathbf{m} \times \mathbf{B} \quad(\mathbf{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}) T=m×B(N⋅m)

System of Circuits with Constant Flux Linkage

FΦ=−∇Wm(N).\mathbf{F}_{\Phi}=-\nabla W_{m} \quad(\mathbf{N}) . FΦ​=−∇Wm​(N).

(TΦ)z=−∂Wm∂ϕ(N⋅m)\left(T_{\Phi}\right)_{z}=-\frac{\partial W_{m}}{\partial \phi} \quad(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}) (TΦ​)z​=−∂ϕ∂Wm​​(N⋅m)

System of Circuits with Constant Currents

FI=∇Wm(N)\mathbf{F}_{I}=\nabla W_{m} \quad(\mathbf{N}) FI​=∇Wm​(N)

(TI)z=∂Wm∂ϕ(N⋅m)\left(T_{I}\right)_{z}=\frac{\partial W_{m}}{\partial \phi} \quad(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}) (TI​)z​=∂ϕ∂Wm​​(N⋅m)

FI=I1I2(∇L12)(N)\mathbf{F}_{I}=I_{1} I_{2}\left(\nabla L_{12}\right) \quad(\mathrm{N}) FI​=I1​I2​(∇L12​)(N)

(TI)z=I1I2∂L12∂ϕ(N⋅m)\left(T_{I}\right)_{z}=I_{1} I_{2} \frac{\partial L_{12}}{\partial \phi} \quad(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}) (TI​)z​=I1​I2​∂ϕ∂L12​​(N⋅m)

6 Time-Varying Fields and Maxwell's Equations

 Fundamental Relations for Electrostatic and Magnetostatic Models  Fundamental  Relations  Electrostatic  Model  Magnetostatic  Model  Governing equations ∇×E=0∇⋅D=ρ∇⋅B=0∇×H=J Constitutive relations  (linear and isotropic media) D=ϵEH=1μB\begin{aligned} &\text { Fundamental Relations for Electrostatic and Magnetostatic Models }\\ &\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline {\begin{array}{c} \text { Fundamental } \\ \text { Relations } \end{array}} & \begin{array}{c} \text { Electrostatic } \\ \text { Model } \end{array} & \begin{array}{c} \text { Magnetostatic } \\ \text { Model } \end{array} \\ \hline \text { Governing equations } & \begin{array}{r} \nabla \times \mathbf{E}=0 \\ \nabla \cdot \mathbf{D}=\rho \end{array} & \begin{array}{r} \nabla \cdot \mathbf{B}=0 \\ \nabla \times \mathbf{H}=\mathbf{J} \end{array} \\ \hline \begin{array}{l} \text { Constitutive relations } \\ \text { (linear and isotropic media) } \end{array} & \mathbf{D}=\epsilon \mathbf{E} & \mathbf{H}=\frac{1}{\mu} \mathbf{B} \\ \hline \end{array} \end{aligned} ​ Fundamental Relations for Electrostatic and Magnetostatic Models  Fundamental  Relations ​ Governing equations  Constitutive relations  (linear and isotropic media) ​​ Electrostatic  Model ​∇×E=0∇⋅D=ρ​D=ϵE​ Magnetostatic  Model ​∇⋅B=0∇×H=J​H=μ1​B​​​

6.1 Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction

Fundamental Postulate for Electromagnetic Induction

∇×E=−∂B∂t\nabla \times \mathbf{E}=-\frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t} ∇×E=−∂t∂B​

The electric field intensity in a region of time-varying magnetic flux density is therefore nonconservative and cannot be expressed as the gradient of a scalar potential.

V=−dΦdt( V)\mathscr{V}=-\frac{d \Phi}{d t} \quad(\mathrm{~V}) V=−dtdΦ​( V)

The electromotive force induced in a stationary closed circuit is equal to the negative rate of increase of the magnetic flux linking the circuit, causing eddy currents.

Idea Transformer

i1i2=N2N1\frac{i_{1}}{i_{2}}=\frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}} i2​i1​​=N1​N2​​

v1v2=N1N2\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\frac{N_{1}}{N_{2}} v2​v1​​=N2​N1​​

(R1)eff =(N1N2)2RL\left(R_{1}\right)_{\text {eff }}=\left(\frac{N_{1}}{N_{2}}\right)^{2} R_{L} (R1​)eff ​=(N2​N1​​)2RL​

(Z1)eff=(N1N2)2ZL\left(Z_{1}\right)_{e f f}=\left(\frac{N_{1}}{N_{2}}\right)^{2} Z_{L} (Z1​)eff​=(N2​N1​​)2ZL​

Real Transformer

v1=L1di1dt−L12di2dtv2=L12di1dt−L2di2dtv_{1}=L_{1} \frac{d i_{1}}{d t}-L_{12} \frac{d i_{2}}{d t} \\ v_{2}=L_{12} \frac{d i_{1}}{d t}-L_{2} \frac{d i_{2}}{d t} v1​=L1​dtdi1​​−L12​dtdi2​​v2​=L12​dtdi1​​−L2​dtdi2​​

where

L1=μSℓN12L2=μSℓN22L12=μSℓN1N2L_{1} =\frac{\mu S}{\ell} N_{1}^{2} \\ L_{2} =\frac{\mu S}{\ell} N_{2}^{2} \\ L_{12} =\frac{\mu S}{\ell} N_{1} N_{2} L1​=ℓμS​N12​L2​=ℓμS​N22​L12​=ℓμS​N1​N2​

L12=kL1L2,k<1,L_{12}=k \sqrt{L_{1} L_{2}}, \quad k<1, L12​=kL1​L2​​,k<1,

where KKK is called the coefficient of coupling.

 Maxwell’s Equations  Differential Form  Integral Form  Significance ∇×E=−∂B∂t∮cE⋅dℓ=−dΦdt Faraday’s law ∇×H=J+∂D∂t∮cH⋅dℓ=I+∫s∂D∂t⋅ds Ampeˋre’s circuital law ∇⋅D=ρ∮sD⋅ds=Q Gauss’s law ∇⋅B=0∮sB⋅ds=0 No isolated magnetic charge \begin{aligned} &\text { Maxwell's Equations }\\ &\begin{array}{|lll|} \hline \text { Differential Form } & \text { Integral Form } & {\text { Significance }} \\ \hline \mathbf{\nabla} \times \mathbf{E}=-\frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t} & \oint_{c} \mathbf{E} \cdot d \ell=-\frac{d \Phi}{d t} \quad \text { Faraday's law } \\ \mathbf{\nabla} \times \mathbf{H}=\mathbf{J}+\frac{\partial \mathbf{D}}{\partial t} & \oint_{c} \mathbf{H} \cdot d \ell=I+\int_{s} \frac{\partial \mathbf{D}}{\partial t} \cdot d \mathbf{s} & \text { Ampère's circuital law } \\ \mathbf{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{D}=\rho & \oint_{s} \mathbf{D} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=Q \quad \text { Gauss's law } \\ \mathbf{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{B}=0 & \oint_{s} \mathbf{B} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=0 & \text { No isolated magnetic charge } \\ \hline \end{array} \end{aligned} ​ Maxwell’s Equations  Differential Form ∇×E=−∂t∂B​∇×H=J+∂t∂D​∇⋅D=ρ∇⋅B=0​ Integral Form ∮c​E⋅dℓ=−dtdΦ​ Faraday’s law ∮c​H⋅dℓ=I+∫s​∂t∂D​⋅ds∮s​D⋅ds=Q Gauss’s law ∮s​B⋅ds=0​ Significance  Ampeˋre’s circuital law  No isolated magnetic charge ​​​
